overview_of_class:
Greek 301 F17 with Professor Jonah Radding

In the aftermath of the Trojan War, Hecuba, queen of Troy, has been enslaved by Agamemnon and the victorious Greeks. To make matters worse, the Greeks intend to sacrifice her daughter, Polyxena, and the body of her last surviving son, Polydorus, has just washed up on shore. Hecuba must cope with the loss of her children and her freedom, and plot revenge against the man responsible for Polydorus' death. We will read the entire play in Greek, examining how Hecuba reacts to the literary past, particularly Homer's Iliad, and how Euripides treats questions of freedom and slavery, justice and vengeance, and Greek attitudes towards women and foreigners.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Successful completion of Greek 201-03, or instructor's permission

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Improved knowledge of ancient Greek; intimate understanding of Euripides' Hecuba, and more generally of ancient Greek tragedy and its literary and historical context(s).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Other: Translation from Greek; grammar review as necessary

descriptions.value:
